column1: I walked one day back toward Antwerp
column2: along that awful road which ran by Contich and Waerloos to Waelhem. Daily along that road the German shells fell nearer to the city
column3: so that whenever one went out to the place that he had visited yesterday he was likely to find himself disagreeably surprised. One day I found myself
column4: (I would not have been there had I known it
column5: ) perhaps a mile inside the range of the enemy's guns. A Red Cross car had dropped me and picked up wounded men instead
column6: and there was nothing for it but to walk back along the road.Along the road from the foremost trenches came a dozen Belgian soldiers
column7: just relieved after twenty-four hours of what it is difficult to describe otherwise than as hell. Muddied from head to heel
column8: they could hardly drag their feet along
column11: I fell in and walked with the last straggler of the little band
column12: while the shrapnel with its long-drawn scream—whew-ew-ew-ew-bang!—broke on either side of us.
